conclusion: The problem involves determining when two objects, A and B, moving along the same straight line, are farthest apart based on their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
The v-t graph shows object A with a straight line (constant acceleration) and object B with a curved line (varying acceleration). Both start at the same position at t = 0.
The separation between the two objects at any time is given by |position_A - position_B|.

premise: Position is the integral of velocity with respect to time.
conclusion: The position of A at time t is x_A(t) = ∫v_A(t)dt, and the position of B at time t is x_B(t) = ∫v_B(t)dt.
From the graph, both objects start at the same position (origin), and both have positive velocities throughout the time interval.
Object A has greater velocity than object B initially.
At time t₁, object B's velocity reaches its minimum (lowest point on the curve).
The v-t graphs of objects A and B intersect at time t₂, marked by a red dot.

premise: The separation between objects increases when their relative velocity is non-zero.
conclusion: The separation reaches its maximum when their relative velocity changes sign.

premise: Object A initially has a greater velocity than object B, and the relative velocity (v_A - v_B) changes sign at t₂ where their velocities become equal.
conclusion: At t₂, object A is ahead of object B, and their separation is maximum.

premise: After t₂, object B's velocity exceeds object A's velocity, causing object B to catch up to object A.
conclusion: After t₂, the separation between the two objects decreases.

premise: The v-t graphs intersect at t₂, and the separation is maximum when their relative velocity changes sign.
conclusion: The two objects are farthest apart at time t₂.
